thread.title: Tech receivers do more than score
thread.title_full: Tech receivers do more than score

author: Brandon Soliz Staff Writer
title: Tech receivers do more than score
text:
Close Duncan Stanley 
Texas Tech wide receiver Tony Brown blocks an Iowa State defender for wide receiver Cameron Batson during the second half of Tech’s 66-31 victory against Iowa State on Saturday   Tech receivers do more than score By Brandon Soliz 0 Duncan Stanley 
Texas Tech wide receiver Tony Brown blocks an Iowa State defender for wide receiver Cameron Batson during the second half of Tech’s 66-31 victory against Iowa State on Saturday   
In Saturday’s game against the Iowa State Cyclones, the Texas Tech offense was able to put up 66 points compared to Iowa State’s 31. 
Four different Tech players caught passing touchdowns for a total of six touchdowns, two of which came by way of senior wide receiver Jakeem Grant and two from freshman receiver Jonathan Giles. 
Not only did the receivers make big plays by catching the ball, Tech offensive coordinator Eric Morris said, but they were also able to aid down the field with their blocking. 
“Up and down. They had some nice (blocks) that sprung some big plays,” Morris said. “I think (the) kids are closer to each other, they’re bought in, blocking with each other, celebrating with each other when they do.” 
This season, Morris introduced a new accolade for the receivers that get down the field and block, and that is a World Wrestling Entertainment-styled championship belt. 
The winner of the belt has yet to be chosen for Saturday’s win, but will be given out after practice this week. 
Previous winners include sophomore receiver Ian Sadler, who did not play against the Cyclones. 
Freshman receiver Tony Brown could be taking the belt after practice, Morris said, because of his two blocks on a 75-yard pass from sophomore quarterback Patrick Mahomes II to Grant. 
Brown was making his first start as a Red Raider, and Tech coach   Brown played as well as he could have expected. 
“I mean, subbing as a true freshman, first start, I thought he handled himself well on the big touchdown pass,” Kingsbury said, “had two awesome blocks for Jakeem to kind of spring him there, made some big catches.” 
Another possibility could be sophomore receiver Ja’Deion High, who Morris said was the best blocking wide receiver during the game. 
“I thought Ja’Deion High was probably the best blocking receiver we had,” Morris said. “He didn’t crush anybody, but his guy didn’t make the play one time, and DeAndre’s (Washington) long run, he blocked the guy 10 seconds down the field.” 
According to ESPN, the Tech offense has a total of a 93.6 offensive efficiency, which is the point contribution of each unit on a team’s scoring margin. 
That stat is currently second in the nation behind fellow Big 12 Conference member Baylor. 
Tech’s offense has been driven on making explosive plays all year and Morris gave credit to each individual player for being willing to help each of their teammates by doing a little more each play. 
“… To me, it’s if a kid wants to do it, he’s going to get out there and do it, if he wants to do it for his teammates and block for each other,” Morris said. “That’s why football is the greatest team sport in America, it’s because these kids actually sacrifice their bodies for each other every single play.” 
Tech is looking to even its record in conference play to 2-2 when the team travels to Lawrence, Kansas, to take on the Kansas Jayhawks at 11 a.m. Saturday at the University of Kansas Memorial Stadium. ×
